title: Introduction to Wireless Networking
note: Provides a basic overview of Wi-Fi (IEEE 802.11), explaining the roles of access points and clients. Introduces the inherent security risk of broadcasting data over the air.

title: Wi-Fi Security Protocols (WEP, WPA, WPA2, WPA3)
note: Covers the evolution of Wi-Fi security. Explains why WEP (RC4) and WPA (TKIP) are deprecated and insecure, and why WPA2 (AES) is the minimum standard. Introduces WPA3's improvements, like SAE.

title: WPA-Personal vs. WPA-Enterprise
note: Contrasts the two main modes. WPA-Personal uses a single Pre-Shared Key (PSK) for everyone. WPA-Enterprise is for corporate environments and authenticates each user individually.

title: WPA-Enterprise, 802.1X, and RADIUS
note: A deeper dive into WPA-Enterprise. Explains the roles of the Supplicant (client), Authenticator (Access Point), and Authentication Server (typically RADIUS) in the 802.1X framework.

title: Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) Types
note: Explains that 802.1X is a framework that uses an EAP method for the actual authentication. Contrasts common types like EAP-TLS (highly secure, uses client/server certificates) and PEAP (common, uses a server certificate and username/password).

title: Wireless Attack: Packet Sniffing
note: Explains how an attacker can capture and read all data on an open (unencrypted) Wi-Fi network using tools like Wireshark. Emphasizes the need for end-to-end encryption like HTTPS.

title: Wireless Attack: The 'Evil Twin' Attack
note: Details the 'Evil Twin' attack, where an attacker sets up a fraudulent Wi-Fi access point with a legitimate-sounding name to trick users into connecting and intercept their traffic.

title: Wireless Attack: Deauthentication Attack
note: Explains the deauthentication attack, where an attacker sends spoofed frames to disconnect a client from an access point, disrupting service or enabling other attacks.

title: Wireless Attack: Cracking WPA/WPA2 Passwords
note: Explains how attackers capture the WPA 4-way handshake and use offline brute-force or dictionary attacks with tools like Aircrack-ng to crack weak pre-shared keys.

title: Overview of Wireless Hacking Tools
note: Provides a brief overview of common tools used by attackers and pentesters. Introduces the Aircrack-ng suite for cracking, Kismet for network discovery, and the Wi-Fi Pineapple as a hardware platform for rogue AP/evil twin attacks.

title: Wireless Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems (WIDS/WIPS)
note: Introduces WIDS/WIPS as enterprise tools that monitor the radio spectrum for malicious activity. Explains their role in detecting rogue access points, evil twins, and other wireless attacks.

title: Understanding Captive Portals
note: Explains how captive portals (public Wi-Fi logins) work by intercepting web traffic and redirecting users to a login page. Highlights that they do not provide encryption for the subsequent session.

title: Best Practice: Use WPA3 or WPA2-AES
note: Emphasizes the most important security setting: always select WPA3 if available, or WPA2 with AES encryption. WEP, WPA, and WPA2-TKIP should never be used.

title: Best Practice: Strong Passphrase and Admin Credentials
note: Highlights two critical password practices: using a long, complex passphrase for WPA-Personal, and immediately changing the default administrator password for the router's web interface.

title: Best Practice: Disable WPS
note: Advises disabling WPS, a feature designed for ease of use but whose PIN method is vulnerable to brute-force attacks that can reveal the main Wi-Fi password.

title: Best Practice: Network Segmentation
note: Explains the security benefit of using a Guest Network. This isolates less-trusted guests and IoT devices from your main network that contains sensitive computers and files.

title: Securing Wireless IoT Devices
note: Discusses the unique challenges of securing IoT devices, which often have poor security features. Emphasizes placing them on a segmented guest network and changing default passwords.

title: Bluetooth Security
note: Provides an overview of Bluetooth security. Discusses the importance of the pairing process and threats like 'Bluesnarfing' (data theft) and 'Bluejacking' (spamming).

title: Mobile Network Security (4G/5G)
note: Gives a high-level introduction to the security architecture of cellular networks. Mentions the role of the SIM card for authentication and the stronger, mutual authentication used in 4G/5G compared to older standards.

title: Best Practices for Public Wi-Fi
note: Provides actionable advice for users on public networks. Emphasizes treating all public Wi-Fi as hostile, verifying network names, and using a trusted VPN to encrypt all traffic.
